properties.Name: AnnuityProduct
properties.Description:
Annuity: A plan that allows individuals to make tax-deferred contributions to a retirement savings account and to select a payout option that meets their income needs upon retirement.

What is an 'Annuity'
An annuity is a contractual financial product sold by financial institutions that is designed to accept and grow funds from an individual and then, upon annuitization, pay out a stream of payments to the individual at a later point in time. The period of time when an annuity is being funded and before payouts begin is referred to as the accumulation phase. Once payments commence, the contract is in the annuitization phase.

Annuities were designed to be a reliable means of securing a steady cash flow for an individual during their retirement years and to alleviate fears of longevity risk, or outliving one's assets.

Annuities can also be created to turn a substantial lump sum into a steady cash flow, such as for winners of large cash settlements from a lawsuit or from winning the lottery.

Defined benefit pensions and Social Security are two examples of lifetime guaranteed annuities that pay retirees a steady cash flow until they pass.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: IssuerPartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: InsuranceProductMarketingName
Columns.Description: The insurer external or marketing name to the public of the Insurance Product.

Columns.Name: AnnuityTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an annuity type.

Columns.Name: AnnuityUponReachingAge
Columns.Description: The age at which the annuity begins in terms of the annuitant's age.

Columns.Name: MinimumAgeForAnnuityPurchase
Columns.Description: The minimum age to make an initial annuity purchase.

Columns.Name: MaximumAgeForAnnuityPurchase
Columns.Description: The maximum age to make an initial annuity purchase.

Columns.Name: MinimumInitialPurchasePaymentAmount
Columns.Description: The minimum amount of an initial annuity purchase payment.

Columns.Name: InitialMinimumPurchasePaymentAmount
Columns.Description: The initial minimum purchase payments amount.

Columns.Name: MinimumSubsequentPurchasePaymentAmount
Columns.Description: The minimum subsequent purchase payments amount.

Columns.Name: LastAgeThatPurchasePaymentsWillBeAccepted
Columns.Description: The last age that purchase payments will be accepted.

Columns.Name: ContractsMustBeIssuedPriorToAnnuitantAge
Columns.Description: The age at which contacts must be issued.

Columns.Name: ContestableClauseStatement
Columns.Description:
Note:
A temporary divider header that is used to separate and organize information for the viewer.

This column is marked 'Logical Only' and is therefore 'for presentation only' and will not be used when generating DDL.

Columns.Name: DeathBenefitClauseStatement
Columns.Description: Death Benefit Clause is the related to the guarantee of payment of the annuity account value to designated account beneficiaries upon the early death of an annuitant.

Columns.Name: EndorsementClause
Columns.Description: Endorsement: an addition written to an insurance policy that includes provisions superseding those of the original policy.

Columns.Name: BailoutProvisionIndicator
Columns.Description: A provision in an annuity contract that allows the owner to surrender the contract, generally without charge, if the renewal interest rates on a fixed annuity drop under the pre-determined amount (usually 1%).

Columns.Name: FreeLookProvisionIndicator
Columns.Description: The provision in an annuity contract stating that the owner of the contract has between ten and 20 days to review the contract immediately after buying it. It gives the buyer the chance to return the contract to the insurer for a total refund and is governed by state regulations, which may vary.

Columns.Name: FreeWithdrawalProvisionIndicator
Columns.Description: The provision in an annuity contract that allows the owner to withdraw some part of its face value, without the imposition of a withdrawal charge, during the accumulation period.

Columns.Name: AnnuitantDrivenAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: Annuity contracts with provisions that trigger upon the death of a designated individual (annuitant). Besides death, an annuitant's reaching of a certain age or becoming disabled, can trigger contract provisions.

Columns.Name: AnnuityCertainAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An immediate annuity income plan from which payments are made for a defined period of time, whether or not the annuitant lives or dies.

Columns.Name: CertificateAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A type of annuity in which the interest rate guarantee period is equal to the surrender charge period.

Columns.Name: ConfinementWaiverIndicator
Columns.Description: An arrangement in which surrender charges are eliminated if the annuity owner must be cared for in a hospital or long-term care facility due to medical necessity.

Columns.Name: DeferredAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity that provides a way to accumulate monies tax-deferred.

Columns.Name: ImmediateAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity contract that begins its payout immediately or within a year.

Columns.Name: AnnuityUponDeathOfOwnerIndicator
Columns.Description:
Annuity whose provisions trigger upon the death, reaching of a certain age, or disability of the contract owner. 

This is in contrast to typical annuities, which designate an annuitant that may or may not be the contract owner.

Columns.Name: AnnuityUponReachingAgeOfOwnerIndicator
Columns.Description:
Annuity whose provisions trigger upon the death, reaching of a certain age, or disability of the contract owner.

 This is in contrast to typical annuities, which designate an annuitant that may or may not be the contract owner.

Columns.Name: AnnuityUponDisabilityIndicator
Columns.Description: Annuity whose provisions trigger upon the death, reaching of a certain age, or disability of the contract owner. This is in contrast to typical annuities, which designate an annuitant that may or may not be the contract owner.

Columns.Name: PeriodCertainAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An income option in an immediate annuity plan whereby the owner of the annuity contract may choose to receive periodic payments for a set period of time, with the payout amount determined by the contract's value and the length of the period of time chosen.

Columns.Name: FlexiblePremiumAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A kind of annuity that may be bought into multiple times in the future. After depositing the initial premium, further investment can be made into the same annuity (similar to a money market account).

Columns.Name: AnnuityPeriodCertainIndicator
Columns.Description: An income option in an immediate annuity plan whereby the owner of the annuity contract may choose to receive periodic payments for a set period of time, with the payout amount determined by the contract's value and the length of the period of time chosen.

Columns.Name: NonqualifiedAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description:
An annuity purchased outside of tax advantaged retirement plan, such as in a taxable brokerage account. These annuities are typically taxed as soon as they have matured or are surrendered.

Nonqualified annuities are purchased with after-tax dollars. This means that when you are ready to take annuity income payments, you won't owe tax on the portion that's considered a return of your original principal. You only pay taxes on earnings.

Columns.Name: NonQualifiedDeferredAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: The return of capital from a non-prescribed annuity plan which is not subject to taxation.

Columns.Name: SingleLifeAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A type of annuity plan in which the periodic payments are made to the annuity contract owner for life, but end after the owner dies.

Columns.Name: SinglePremiumAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A kind of annuity into which funds cannot be deposits after the initial investment. Fixed-rate annuities are commonly of this type, requiring a second annuity purchase should the contract owner decide to invest more money at a future date.

Columns.Name: TaxFreeTransfersIndicator
Columns.Description: An activity whereby owners of variable annuity contracts may move assets from one sub-account to another without the imposition of tax liability on these funds.

Columns.Name: LifeAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity that continues to pay out as long as the annuitant is alive.

Columns.Name: OffshoreAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: Annuities which allow for tax-deferred account accumulation and build up through o shore investment funds.

Columns.Name: PrivateAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description:
The term "private annuity" generally refers to an annuity for the lifetime of the annuitant by a purchaser of the property who does not otherwise issue annuities. 

The private annuity is contract between the annuitant and someone other than an insurance company or entity regularly engaged in the business of issuing annuity contracts. 

The most typical situation where a private annuity is used is when an elderly family member transfers assets to a younger family member who makes an unsecured promise to pay a lifetime annuity to the elderly family member

Columns.Name: PeriodCertainOptionIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuitization-method option whereby the annuitant may choose to receive periodic payments for a specific period of time, with the payout amount determined by the contract's value and the length of the period of time chosen.

Columns.Name: GuaranteedInterestContractAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity in which the interest rate is guaranteed for a specific amount of time.

Columns.Name: QualifiedAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: Qualified annuities are annuities purchased for funding an IRA, 403(b) tax- deferred annuity, or other type of retirement arrangements, generally with paid premiums reducing current income tax and the use of tax-deferred accumulations.

Columns.Name: TaxDeferredAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A contract for people who want to save on a tax-deferred basis for many years, and then convert to a payout schedule upon retirement.

Columns.Name: TaxShelteredAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A tax-deferred retirement savings plan for teachers and some non- pro t agency employees where contributors, employees and employers may invest a portion of their income, pre-tax, in annuities or mutual funds.

Columns.Name: JointAndSurvivorAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A life annuity in which there are two annuitants, usually spouses, known as joint annuitants Annuity payments continue as long as either annuitant is alive.

Columns.Name: TermCertainAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity plan in which predefined income payments are provided over a pre-determined number of years.

Columns.Name: PensionAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity incorporated in a pension or other qualified retirement plan set up by a corporation, labor union, government, or other organization for its employees, including pro t-sharing plans, stock bonus and employee stock ownership plans, thrift plans, target benefit plans, money purchase plans, and defined benefit plans.

Columns.Name: UnbundledAnnuityContractIndicator
Columns.Description: Annuity contracts that permit purchasers to choose and pay for certain optional features they want in their contracts.

Columns.Name: StraightLifeAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A straight life annuity is one which ceases on the annuitant's death. It is not included in the annuitant's estate.

Columns.Name: TermAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description:
A term annuity is paid for a specific term i.e. 10 years. 

Under the "term certain" clause the annuity pays for the term stated regardless of the death of the annuitant.

Columns.Name: TwoPhaseAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description:
Two-phase annuity: Most annuities sold today are two-phase annuities. 

Phase 1 is the accumulation phase where contributions are made and, hopefully, grown over time. 

Phase 2 is the distribution phase where the insurance company distributes the funds from phase 1. The phase 2 distributions can be in the form of a lump sum, regular withdrawals, or an annuitized income stream.

Columns.Name: TemporaryAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: An annuity that is set to expire after the passing of a pre-established period of time.

Columns.Name: FixedPeriodAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A fixed Period Annuity Payout option for a specified number of years instead of for a lifetime.

Columns.Name: AShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: A-Share Variable Annuities Annuity contracts in which sales charges are incurred at time of investment or premium payment. A-share contracts typically have no surrender charges.

Columns.Name: BShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: B-Share Variable Annuities Variable annuity contracts characterized by deferred sales charges, which typically range from 5% to 7% in the  first year, and subsequently decline to zero after  five to seven years. B-shares are the most common form of annuity contracts sold.

Columns.Name: CShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: C-Share Variable Annuities Variable annuity contracts with no up-front or contingent deferred sales charges, which offer full liquidity to contract holders at any time

Columns.Name: IShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: I-Share Variable Annuity Also known as fee-based variable annuities in which an investor pays one fee to have the portfolio managed by an investment advisor. I-shares do not offer a sales commission to the advisor. However, the advisor assesses fees for the services, including the I-share contract, which is agreed upon by the client.

Columns.Name: LShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: L-Share Variable Annuities Variable annuity contracts that typically have shorter surrender periods, such as three or four years. L-share variable annuities typically have higher mortality and expense (M&E) charges than B-share annuities.

Columns.Name: OShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: O-Share Variable Annuities Annuity contracts which do not impose up-front sales charges, while, typically, possessing surrender charge periods similar to B-shares. Mortality and expense charges are assessed, and progressively decline throughout the surrender period.

Columns.Name: XShareVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: X-share variable annuity contracts credit an additional amount or bonus to the contract value, which is calculated as a percentage of purchase payments added to the contract at, or subsequent to, contract issue. Contract charges may be higher in X-share products.

Columns.Name: BusinessAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description: Business annuities are a special class of annuities that are specifically designed for small business owners. A business annuity can only be used to fund individual retirement accounts for the company's employees. The money from the annuity is tax-deferred for the owner and adds to the IRA's value for the employee. Small business owners can also set up business annuities that rely on pre-tax paycheck withholdings to fund employee IRAs. This makes it a cost-effective way for some small businesses to offer retirement plans, though employees don't benefit from the employer's business annuity directly when they retire.

Columns.Name: AnnuityClassId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an annuity class.

Columns.Name: AnnuityStructureTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an annuity structure type.

Columns.Name: IndexYieldCalculationMethodTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an index yield calculation method type.

life annuity in which there are two annuitants, usually spouses, known as joint annuitants Annuity payments continue as long as either annuitant is alive.","isNullable":true,"name":"JointAndSurvivorAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"TermCertainAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"An annuity plan in which predefined income payments are provided over a pre-determined number of years.","isNullable":true,"name":"TermCertainAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"PensionAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"An annuity incorporated in a pension or other qualified retirement plan set up by a corporation, labor union, government, or other organization for its employees, including pro t-sharing plans, stock bonus and employee stock ownership plans, thrift plans, target benefit plans, money purchase plans, and defined benefit plans.","isNullable":true,"name":"PensionAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"UnbundledAnnuityContractIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Annuity contracts that permit purchasers to choose and pay for certain optional features they want in their contracts.","isNullable":true,"name":"UnbundledAnnuityContractIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"StraightLifeAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A straight life annuity is one which ceases on the annuitant's death. It is not included in the annuitant's estate.","isNullable":true,"name":"StraightLifeAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"TermAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A term annuity is paid for a specific term i.e. 10 years. 

Under the "term certain" clause the annuity pays for the term stated regardless of the death of the annuitant.","isNullable":true,"name":"TermAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"TwoPhaseAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Two-phase annuity: Most annuities sold today are two-phase annuities. 

Phase 1 is the accumulation phase where contributions are made and, hopefully, grown over time. 

Phase 2 is the distribution phase where the insurance company distributes the funds from phase 1. The phase 2 distributions can be in the form of a lump sum, regular withdrawals, or an annuitized income stream.","isNullable":true,"name":"TwoPhaseAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"TemporaryAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"An annuity that is set to expire after the passing of a pre-established period of time.","isNullable":true,"name":"TemporaryAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"FixedPeriodAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A fixed Period Annuity Payout option for a specified number of years instead of for a lifetime.","isNullable":true,"name":"FixedPeriodAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"AShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A-Share Variable Annuities Annuity contracts in which sales charges are incurred at time of investment or premium payment. A-share contracts typically have no surrender charges.","isNullable":true,"name":"AShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"BShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"B-Share Variable Annuities Variable annuity contracts characterized by deferred sales charges, which typically range from 5% to 7% in the  first year, and subsequently decline to zero after  five to seven years. B-shares are the most common form of annuity contracts sold.","isNullable":true,"name":"BShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"CShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"C-Share Variable Annuities Variable annuity contracts with no up-front or contingent deferred sales charges, which offer full liquidity to contract holders at any time","isNullable":true,"name":"CShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"IShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"
I-Share Variable Annuity Also known as fee-based variable annuities in which an investor pays one fee to have the portfolio managed by an investment advisor. I-shares do not offer a sales commission to the advisor. However, the advisor assesses fees for the services, including the I-share contract, which is agreed upon by the client.","isNullable":true,"name":"IShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"LShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"
L-Share Variable Annuities Variable annuity contracts that typically have shorter surrender periods, such as three or four years. L-share variable annuities typically have higher mortality and expense (M&E) charges than B-share annuities.","isNullable":true,"name":"LShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"OShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"O-Share Variable Annuities Annuity contracts which do not impose up-front sales charges, while, typically, possessing surrender charge periods similar to B-shares. Mortality and expense charges are assessed, and progressively decline throughout the surrender period.","isNullable":true,"name":"OShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"XShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"X-share variable annuity contracts credit an additional amount or bonus to the contract value, which is calculated as a percentage of purchase payments added to the contract at, or subsequent to, contract issue. Contract charges may be higher in X-share products.","isNullable":true,"name":"XShareVariableAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"BusinessAnnuityIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"Business annuities are a special class of annuities that are specifically designed for small business owners. A business annuity can only be used to fund individual retirement accounts for the company's employees. The money from the annuity is tax-deferred for the owner and adds to the IRA's value for the employee. Small business owners can also set up business annuities that rely on pre-tax paycheck withholdings to fund employee IRAs. This makes it a cost-effective way for some small businesses to offer retirement plans, though employees don't benefit from the employer's business annuity directly when they retire.","isNullable":true,"name":"BusinessAnnuityIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"AnnuityClassId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of an annuity class.","isNullable":true,"name":"AnnuityClassId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"AnnuityStructureTypeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of an annuity structure type.","isNullable":true,"name":"AnnuityStructureTypeId"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"AnnuityProduct.cdm.json/AnnuityProduct","name":"IndexYieldCalculationMethodTypeId"},"dataType":"integer","description":"The unique identifier of an index yield calculation method type.","isNullable":true,"name":"IndexYieldCalculationMethodTypeId"}]}}}
Properties.Description:
Annuity: A plan that allows individuals to make tax-deferred contributions to a retirement savings account and to select a payout option that meets their income needs upon retirement.

What is an 'Annuity'
An annuity is a contractual financial product sold by financial institutions that is designed to accept and grow funds from an individual and then, upon annuitization, pay out a stream of payments to the individual at a later point in time. The period of time when an annuity is being funded and before payouts begin is referred to as the accumulation phase. Once payments commence, the contract is in the annuitization phase.

Annuities were designed to be a reliable means of securing a steady cash flow for an individual during their retirement years and to alleviate fears of longevity risk, or outliving one's assets.

Annuities can also be created to turn a substantial lump sum into a steady cash flow, such as for winners of large cash settlements from a lawsuit or from winning the lottery.

Defined benefit pensions and Social Security are two examples of lifetime guaranteed annuities that pay retirees a steady cash flow until they pass.
